title: Clear WA
description:
Fully restored, excellent condition 1964 Porsche 356 SC Cabriolet.  A fantastic condition 356 professionally renewed by top restoration specialists with over $140,000 spent for this high quality work.   A  comprehensive, rotisserie metal restoration and refurbishment was completed by Byers Custom & Restoration of Auburn, WA and top-quality subcontracting shops in 2003, including replacing the floor pans, longitudinals,  repairing and aligning the body panels, repainting the exterior in attractive, metallic silver/green similar to Aston Martin Olive Green.   A new, black German canvas soft top and  black leather upholstery was installed.  Chrome wheels with correct hubcaps and quality radial tires are installed. No expense was spared in renewing the car with correct new, restored and re-chromed parts.  Additional photos and video  are presented in this site's photo gallery showing the restored undercarriage,  suspension, chassis, and driveline   
 A replacement 1964 356SC engine was rebuilt to 1.7 liters and installed by Denny Aker,  a leading 356 restoration and engine builder and runs extremely well. Case stamping on third member of case is P☆813334☆ is a correct year and type for a 356SC engine. This SC has a rebuilt four-speed manual transaxle, and is original to the car. Denny Aker and serviced since 1984 by  Aker's Porsche of Seattle, WA.  
Cabin finishes include replacement black leather upholstery with matching door panels, gray carpeting, and Coco floor mats. Lap belts are fitted, Blaupunkt Frankfurt AM/FM/SW restored factory radio, leather steering wheel and other amenities. The body-colored dashboard has restored, VDO instrumentation that includes a 6k-rpm tachometer, a 120mph speedometer, and a combination gauge for oil temperature and fuel level. The five-digit mechanical odometer shows 73,336 believed to be original miles.
Acquired by the present, private owner in 1984, (believe to be third owner since new),  this beautiful, turn-key  356SC cabriolet is now offered with historical documentation and restoration receipts, restoration photo album, a  Porsche Certificate of Authenticity (COA), and a clean Washington state title. A factory 356 Cabriolet hardtop and factory toolkit  is available from the selling dealer at an additional, reasonable price. Available to view at our showroom in Carnation, WA.
Details from Porsche COA:  VIN: 160170  Mfr/Delivery Date:  03/19/1964  Original Engine No. 820759. Transaxel No. 76893  Original Paint Color:  Champagne Yellow/6405.  Interior: Black Leather. Optional equipment: Dunlop Tires, Set of Cocoa-Fiber Mats.

title: 1962 Porsche 356 Super 90 Coupe-Silver/Black. Significant Restoration of CA Black Plate Car.
description:
Price reflects significant, recently completed restoration work our believed to be matching number Super 90 Coupe. Professionaly  rebuilt, S90 engine and transaxel.  2018-19 work professional underbody restoration.   Currently Silver with black interior but considering installation of a new, red Leather interior. A fast appreciating classic.  Presently price at $ 105,995 

Our `62 Porsche 356B T6 S90 has received siginificant professional restoration-A rare and fun car to own and drive and an appreciating collectable.  The Super 90 engine model is the top of the 356B line, and is a California Black plate and Blue Plate survivor. Previous owner had the engine professionally rebuilt in Los Angeles, CA and built to claimed 120-125 dyno-tested horsepower. The 741 model 356B 4spd transaxel was also rebuilt at that time. Rebuild is many years ago, but few miles since. Body/paint was professionally restored by Steve Huber and has not been rarely driven since. Upper Body was stripped to bare metal, and carefully prepped for paint. Car requires some light, final assembly. Car looks terrific in silver. Has optional speedster aluminum side trim. Work required to complete the car is primarily installing newly powder coated engine tin (correct S90 colors), re-installation of a few components in the dash, install glass, and some trim and other misc. work. This is a very solid, very good condition S90 coupe.
color: Silver with Black Interior (new red leather seat and matching red interior planned)
engine: S90. Number is correctly located in year production range of VIN 117795
options: Blaupunkt Frankfurt AM/FM/Shorwave factory radio, Driving lamps, and more.

title: Clear WA Title
description:
Recent SALE:  1972 DE TOMASO PANTERA COUPE CHASSIS NO. THPNMB02410 This early, 1972 Pre-L version with chrome bumpers, a two-pod dash and a rare flat rear decklid is finished in a rare, one year only factory red/orange paint with a black interior. Same enthusiast owner the last 20 years.

View Walk around video at the web link provided in this ad... View Engine start up and run video at:  https://youtu.be/Z7dXwM6pNlM

Note: We will be mounting and balancing a set of 4 used. good condition Radial tires on a set of 7"and 8" Factory original Pantera DeTomaso Campagnola  wheels and installing on the car with new photos provided in this ad.soon..The 5 spoke, American Racing wheels shown in photos are retained by the seller and not included in sale.    

Power provided by a mid-mounted 351cu.in. Cleveland V8 matched with the better performing, early close-ratio transmission, both believed to be original to this car. Some minor spares and removed parts and manuals included. A later model header, with original, quad-outlet exhaust system with Ansa tips, aftermarket alum. intake manifold, ribbed valve covers. A Deluxe Marti report is on order. This Pantera is in overall very good, mainly original condition with much better than average unibody condition. The car starts and drives very well, with good power, quiet exhaust, solid brakes and easy shifting. Here are some details from a comprehensive inspection (available in PDF) by Mike Thomas, Pantera owner, restorer, and president of Panteras Northwest: Underside/Chassis: “In general, the underside of the car is in very good condition. No evidence of serious rust was found. Only two minor dents in the outer frame, one on each side, were noted and likely due to attempts to jack the car up from the wrong location. The rear crossmember which typically is in very rough shape due to jacking the car is clean and straight. There does not appear to be any outward rusting of any frame members front to rear. There is some minor rust through of the valence under the radiator as is typical of an early Panteras. but the valence itself is very straight. There is the usual light transmission oil deposits on the bottom of the ZF transmission” . Paint Trim and Body: Paint is very presentable and had a light polishing before the review. No serious blemishes were noted. The stainless trim, bumpers, mirrors, and badging are likewise in a very good, shiny condition. Sighting in the body lines of the car from the front, back and sides does not reveal any twisting or other evidence of accident damage to the structure. A magnet test around the lower half of the car did not reveal any significant body filler or Bondo. The rockers have been repainted at some point with some minor overrun to the body above the rockers rear of the doors. There is no bubbling through on any of the rockers. The pinch welds along the bottom of the rockers are clean and straight, and no telltale rust came out of any of the rocker drain openings. The doors open a bit stiff but smooth, but otherwise open, close and latch as they should. The front and rear decklids open and close/latch smoothly and as expected. Weather seals around the doors and decklids are in good, supple condition. Body gaps are consistent around the car. Many of the usual telltale cracks at the shoulders above the upper edge of the rear deck opening, around the taillights and other places do not appear to be in evidence. All the glass is in good condition. Interior: The interior appears to be original save for installation of an aftermarket stereo head unit with speakers in the doors. There is a good bit of the typical delamination of the dash covering above the heater box and in the pocket above the glove box, but the dash covering is otherwise in very good condition. The original seats show only three very small separations of the outer side bolster from the center section on the driver’s seat bottom and back. This can be easily sewn back together by a competent upholstery shop. The passenger seat is in good condition. Key areas to address: ● Headlights are non-operative: this may only be a relay or blown fuse  Note from dealer: There is an apparent relay or wiring problem. Headlight “doors” open and close via 2 wires that can be contacted to battery terminals -switching wires closes the headlights. ● Steering rack bushing has failed: rack needs to be rebuilt and the outer right bushing replacedDealer Note: This upgrade Bronze bushing is ordered and will be installed before 8/22

● Engine run needs to be sorted and tuned: seemed to run a bit rough on start-up and the choke does not engage to hold idle on cold start. ● Radiator overflow tank needs to be repaired: rust at the bottom:  Dealer Note: This tank was professionally welded/repaired and works fine.  Summary: “This appears to be a very solid car. The body structure top and bottom are very clean and straight with minimal evidence of rust. There has been minor modification for drivability to the engine and suspension. It does show wear and lack of functionality in the usual electrical, mechanical, and cosmetic areas for a 50-year-old Pantera that has been fairly-well cared for and driven. This car appears to be an excellent candidate for either light repairs to begin enjoying now or a full restoration. Early flat-deck pre-L Panteras such as this in solid condition have become rarer than the later models sold under the Ford program".

A few highlights of the car: * Offered from an enthusiast with 20 years of ownership. * Pacific NW car that has been carefully stored and maintained-The condition indicates this car has been in good hands since new. * In August, 2021 Mike Thomas, an experienced Pantera inspector and restorer and Pantera club president inspected the car. His 4 page report is available in PDF to help the buyer evaluate the car from an expert's inspection notes. Inspection noted the car “ presents very well and is detailed-out nicely.” *This is an excellent example of the 'pre-L' Pantera * The original Factory Pantera 15” Campagnola wheels, intake manifold, painted valve covers and air cleaner. A pair of Pantera manuals are included. This rare Pantera is available to view and inspect at Giordano’s Vintage Motors located in Carnation WA. Offered for sale at $85,995.

title: 2022 WA Title Included
description:
1960 Volvo Custom Sports Roadster  

Completed by Giordano’s Vintage Motors (GVM) in 2022 for our client, this unique, hand built, supperlegga constructed steel roadster is now on consignment with our dealership. Below is a description and comments on this custom build.   
 
Body:Superleggera style construction. ¾ steel tubing with steel body panels welded and riveted to this framing. Overall high quality construction with significant structural upgrading by our shop in the style of period road racing cars. The hand-built steel body and interior is in the style of 50s or 60s Lotus sports racers, and Italian sports and racing cars. The original, steel front-hinged bonnet has custom air scoop and chrome bonnet hold-down pins,  GVM designed and fabricated many aluminum panels in the engine compartment and interior in a vintage race car style.  
 
Frame/Chassis; The original ladder frame in parts was claimed by previous owner to be from a 1960 Volvo 544.The original suspension, rear end, brakes and steering were also Volvo 544, now upgraded to later Volvo P1800. This frame was cut down to allow lower seat height . Almost all of the frame the rear bulkhead back, including bracing for the fuel cell. and firewall forward (except part of the front frame rails). We fabricated, :1-1/2 steel tubing to support the frame and provide passenger and driver side impact protection. Steel bracing and aluminum cladding in the style of period road racing cars was fabricated. . 
 
Drivetrain: The car is powered by a Volvo P1800 B20  2 liter inline 4 engine professionally built by Autosport of Seattle with all stock with a D cam high end rebuild with break-in miles only. engine Engine was completely re-machined with replacement valves, new bearings,  gaskets and an upgraded front cover and seal system to prevent leaks common with this engine.  Fuel system included a new fuel cell, dual, OEM Italian Weber 40 DCOE carburetors  and new Volvo sports Intake manifold.  The transmission is a factory P1800 four-speed overdrive manual. The overdrive is currently not activated and is bypassed. Fuel system new proximally 10 gallon fuel cell. Electric feel pump. 1960s Corvette Radiator. New Dodge colt rack and pinion steering system, Steering column is an aftermarket custom unit. New period style gauges. Push button starter. Racing style electrical shut off switch. New clutch kit hoses. 
 
Suspension and Brake system.  Front suspension is “modern”, Volvo 740 including lower control arms, spindles.disk brakes and adjustable, coil over front struts. 
Four link rear suspension utilizes a Volvo P1800 narrowed, axel assembly, new axles, adjustable coil springs with KYB performance shocks and rebuilt P1800 disc brakes.  Custom parking brake with leather boot. 
 
Wheels are Volvo 15 inch steel wheels in the style of 1950s Jaguar racers. . 
The custom exhaust system includes ceramic coated tube headers with full stainless exhaust system-a single piper splits to dual pipes coming out the back. Not installed on the car presently but included with this car is a custom, stainless steel rear bumper.. This bumper is included with the car and will require removal of the tail lamps where the bumper mounting frame mount is located.   
 
Interior: The interior design was designed similar to 1950s Ferrari sports cars. Our client requested a vintage race car style which fit the body of the car. The custom built interior by GVM and Jimmy’s Upholstery features custom built leather seats, headrest, quilted door and side panels with side pockets for map sunglasses etc. and rear bulkhead panels with quilted panels carried through into the engine compartment.  Wood Steering wheel, aluminum center dash new carpeting with leather in vinyl edging  

Upgrades added to the car by GVM include all new wiring with new  electrical panels, switches and guages. New fuel-cell and removable, steel access body cover, stainless roll hoop, drivers rear Cowel with leather headrest with hidden storage compartment with interior actuated latch assembly. (note in photos we did not have headrest latched and its popped up at rear). Four-point safety belt system with quick relase, cam locks.  

Other detailing and features include custom-made, Tail lamp assemblies with aluminum housing with Austin Healey glass lenses.  Custom aluminum windshield frame with GVM0built alloy side supports Lexan windshield, and Porsche 356 Speedster aero mirror. Steel front mesh front grill. A variety of vintage and new Volvo badging and emblems are included but not installed on the car.  

This is a stylish, one of a kind, custom sports car that is fun to drive, and would be a special car in an enthusiast’s collection. Clear, WA State USA title in our dealership name.  The car is ready to ship worldwide.
engine: Freshly rebuilt Volvo P1800 2 liter with dual Webers

title: Original Mount Rainier National Park Tour Bus
description:
Original Mount Rainier National Park Tour Bus

RARE Scenic Roof Sightseer Windows  This unique and well documented Mt. Rainer Natl. Park tour bus has a significant history in the Northwest, transporting countless visitors to Paradise and other park locations. Historic enough for a museum, this bus carries a unique story and a history of cherished memories and would be welcome and enjoyed by many if used as a tour bus or RV.. Owner's Description Follows:

Based on VIN history, this is 1 of 2 Mt Rainier National Park tour busses and the other is unknown if it still exists. As seen in the photos, there is an original park brochure and 3 post cards displaying the bus. The destination scroll includes "Seattle, Tacoma, Sunrise (Lodge), Paradise (Lodge), Special and Rainier Nat’l Park."

Converted to an RV Motorhome in 1972. Original blueprints for conversion included.
Owner's Description Below:

Caterpillar 1150 Diesel
4 Speed manual with 2 speed rear end.
Both motor and trans have recently been gone through with various updates & repairs. 
All new batteries. 
All new wheels and tires. (6)
Onan generator serviced and runs well. However last trip, a gas leak began at one of the valves. Minor repair needed, easy access. 
Gas stove works great. 
Refrigerator and freezer work great. 
Water, and shower unknown as I never tried them, water pump activates... 
Toilet flushes, flush valve sticks. (this is the reason I haven't run the water further)
Fresh water and black water holding tanks seem to be complete and holding residual water with no leaks. 
Headlights / taillights work. 
Marker lights (roof corners) currently disconnected. 
Front and rear electric heaters work. 
Many outlets not working. 
Windshield wipers work - need new blades. 
Roof a/c works
Air horns work great and sound like a train lol! 
New 30 amp power cord wired in, powers the coach great. 

There are additional pieces of glass which I believe are spare windshields. There are also the rest of the original scenic window shades. Included are various additional interior and exterior trim pieces etc.

Registration / documented owner history following Mt Rainier National Park, dated back to 1972 (or earlier). Many original owners manuals and diagrams plus handwritten driver logs.

The remaining roof scenic windows are one of the most rare and unique things about this bus and one of my favorite features!

Reason for selling: We are a larger family with 5 children and need a motorhome large enough for traveling. We have determined it just is not realistic to make this work for us.

Needs: Overall the “bones” of this bus are very decent. There are areas of rust. A few of these spots are significant. Most are surface.

Ideal candidate for motorhome, tour bus, tiny home, mobile espresso and so many other uses!

Currently stored indoor, RV Garage. Located in Woodinville WA. 
Offered at $ 59,995

​Contact Jim Giordanoe at 425.985 4259

model: Devin SS Tube Frame ASM Drag Racer/Street 396 FI
description:
Price is for completed car. 1964 Devin-Corvette A Sports Modified Street/Drag Coupe. Under re-construction at our shop. Race/Track/Street - Under re-construction in our shop. Our unique 1964 Devin-Corvette rebuild and upgrade and repowering highlights our team's capabilities in executing the design and construction of unique vehicles and compnent upgrades for our customers. Built to drag race in the 1960s in the ASM racing class, this well designed steel tube frame car was built using 1964 Corvette components: 327 Corvette engine and trans, dash, guages etc. We have repowered the car with a rebuilt, 1967 Chevrolet 396 engine using a period Hilborne mechanical fuel injection system with high rise chrome stacks to our own design electronic fuel injection system - retaining the wild Hilborn Dragster look with flexible, reliable fuel delivery for street or track. We have extensively upgrades the original steel tube frame for added safety and driveability. Features included Wilwood 4 wheel power disk brakes, GM 12 Bolt narrowed rear with custom rear suspension, coil over front suspension with modern steering rack, automatic transmission and fuel cell. We are restoring the original, Devin fiberglass body with steel roof, steel doors with rollup windows, and aluminum and fiberglass inner structure. One of 3 known Big Body/Devin SS coupe conversion bodies. Our plan is to create a custom 1970s look two tone metalflake paint scheme with custom period graphics, or we can paint to customers requirements. An exciting and unique car that will be ready for the street, nostalgic drags, car show and events in early 2019.

title: 1973 Datsun 240Z – Rebuilt, Weber-Carbed Engine. Originally Orange, now ’73 Lime Green. Nice Car
description:
Seller’s Description:
1973 Datsun 240Z – Rebuilt, Weber-Carbed Engine. Competition Orange, (original Factory color) 71,842 miles

Rebuilt Engine with Weber Carbs Cylinder head replaced with earlier, better 1971 240Z cylinder head. Sale includes a set of 4 now vintage Slotted Aluminum wheels with older radial tires shown in a couple earlier photos, Hitachi/Datsun Am Fm stock radio and other spare parts and a repair manual. 

Desirable last-year 240Z Classic Japanese Sports car.  Terrific condition body with excellent panel gaps and fit; Very Straight, sound condition with only minor flaws in original dash, new seats covers and carpeting etc.
A solid, desirable 1973 model. Currently 1973 240Z line green, but engine compartment and interior body of car is original excellent orange paint - easy repaint to this original color.

1973 Datsun 240Z with a rebuilt Engine, 4-speed manual trans.

Here are notes from long time, previous owner: " This car has not been a an occassional, daily driver for about 15 years. I have driven it around the block one or twice a year and recently drained the tank and put new gas in it. Less than 1000 miles since comprehensive engine rebuild. Rebuild included hot tanking, cylinder honing, new pistons/rings, bearings, crank polishing/balancing, oil pump, complete timing chain kit, rebuilt 1971 240Z head ( 71 head has higher compression than 73 head, also has steel seats instead of brass). Rebuilt alternator, water pump, starter. driver "I'm not the original owner but as far as I can tell, the car has never been in even a minor accident. I did have it painted years ago. Car was sanded to bare metal or original primer. Some minor dent repair done in various spots. Car was originally the competition orange color. Yellow/green paint now is matched to a factory original color. Floor pans have been restored with a procedure of grinding rust out and brush applying a anti-rust primer. Suspension strut cartridges were replaced with KYB shocks. This was many years ago but probably on have 5000 miles on them.. Exhaust was replaced at time of engine rebuild with a header, Wolverine Glaspak, and resonator/muffler. The clutch was also replaced at the time of the engine rebuild. I replaced the pressure plate, clutch disk and throwout bearing. Front ball joints have been replaced. Steering is pretty tight unlike most 240z. Front end is very stable on the freeway. Much brake work was done but again it was many years ago. Front disks were turned as well as rear drums. I just replaced the rear wheel cylinders as they didn't survive the extended garaging. The brake lines also got a good flush. As you can see by the pictures the original side-draft dashpot carbs are not on the car. I retrofited the carbs with the 240Z weber upgrade kit. I still have the old dashpots and linkages if you want to restore back to original. I also have the original 1973 head along with a bunch of other misc. parts. Even a spare back glass." Note: These notes from long-term owner was written years ago before I purchased the car. Current price reflects recent work and significant increase in market value in similar condition 240Zs.

title: 1957 La Dawrie Custom Q.T. – 1957 VW Karmann Ghia Chassis.
description:
We love the rare and unusual, be it production automobiles, motorcycles, kit cars or home builts. With our 1957 La Dawrie Q.T./Karman Ghia with a ‘50s customized body and unusual hydraulics, rare is hardly the right word. One-off, one of one might be a better description. Note photos show car as  it looks before we sold the car and our customer partly took it apart for professional restoration and updating..See this rare car in our Carnation showroom/
We have included a brief history of the La Dawrie custom bodies below. Here are a few choice details about this car. Perhaps most importantly, it runs and drives very well! The warmed over VW engine moves this lightweight car down the road, with good handling and braking. The La Dawrie Q.T. body has been cleverly customized, with a 1955 Packard Clipper the inspiration for the rear tailfins (with actual ’55 Clipper Taillamp lens), and the unique, 1957 Packard Hawk design clearly visible in the nose and even the rear end treatment. I can see a little early Corvette rear end and Devin or Ferrari 250 GTO in the front end. In the true spirit of custom car builders of this era, the car has unique, electric motor actuated front suspension/ride height, hood and rear engine lid, the later utilizing '50s passenger car convertible top motors! The quality of the fiberglass custom work is done to a very high standard, the the La Dawrie body is in excellent condition, with little cracking or flaws. The chassis and drivetrain are tried and true VW Karmann Ghia. The car is titled as a 1957 Karmann Ghia.

This car was recently purchased by Giordano's Vintage Motors, after comming out of storage since the 1980s. We are discussing the completion of the interior, dash and light paint restoration as needed. This car runs and drives very well, is incredicbly rare, and is for sale.

La Dawri History: The LaDawri Q.T. Custom & larger, Conquest was designed and built by Les A. Dawes of British Columbia, Canada and is recognized as Canada’s first fiberglass sports car. The Conquest was first shown at the Pacific International Exhibition at Vancouver Canada in 1956 as the Cavalier. Original plans were to create a complete sports car for sale and distribution throughout the United States and Canada. The body itself is fiberglass and was designed to take a wheelbase of 100 to 104 inches and a tread of 56 to 58 inches. This covered Corvettes, Thunderbirds, and the like of the day. However, within a year, the car, family, and company moved to Long Beach California where production began and the car debuted on the front cover of Road &Track in July 1957. From this point forward, the car was known as the “Conquest”. Soon, Dawes expanded both the number of designs available and the sizes of each design
as well. New models included Quest Q.T., Daytona, Sebring, and Del Mar.

description:
This is a very solid, well maintained 1972 MGB convertible.  The seller has owned MGBs for over 40 years, and this has been his summer "driver" for many years but has decided to put the funds of the sale of his well-loved MGB into an electric, riding lawn mower to mow his quite large yard!  Here is his brief comments on his car.  "I bought this MGB in 2001 and flew to Witchita Kansas to drive it to Seattle (which I did after a 2 days of waiting for parts in Cheyenne Wyoming.  For the next 10+ years, it was my daily driver. title: 1981 Honda CBX 1100 6 Cylinder Stock Parts off Bike, With Touring Equipment
description:
1981 Honda CBX 1100. Mainly original with minor upgrades. Includes full touring gear, and not shown but included, the original parts from the stock bike taken off when first purchased when touring gear was installed. Missing front fender and rear seat support.

 

About this model:

Honda had produced a Honda RC series six-cylinder race bike in the mid-1960s, but the CBX was Honda's first production 6 cylinder road bike. The CBX's advanced DOHC 24-valve inline six-cylinder engine was its outstanding feature; but in other respects the bike was conventional, having telescopic forks, a tubular frame, twin rear shocks and straight handlebars.[4][6]

Although bulky, the engine was wide only at the top. The width across the crankshaft was relatively narrow as the CBX had a stacked engine accessory arrangement, whereby the alternator and ignition items were positioned behind the cylinder block. This arrangement produced an acceptable engine width low down and moved critical items out of harm's way in the event of grounding.[6]

Journalist L. J. K. Setright wrote of the CBX's width: "Don't tell me that its engine is too wide: It is no wider than the legs of a rider, so it adds nothing to the frontal area, and personally I would rather have my legs shielded by a cylinder apiece than exposed to every blow Thanks to Wikipedia for above information

An article about this Model:  Retrospective: BSA B25 Starfire 250: 1968-1970
By Clement Salvadori - October 22, 2007
(This Retrospective article was published in the October 2007 issue of Rider.)

STORY and photography BY CLEMENT SALVADORI

This little machine was an anomaly when it appeared on the showroom floors in 1968; though it was a rather attractive motorcycle, it was powered by an old-fashioned single-cylinder OHV engine.

BSA had been building 250 singles since 1938, and some dim bulb up in marketing thought there was still a market for a little plodder…if you dressed it up real pretty.

It was a tough engine, slightly undersquare with a 67mm bore, 70mm stroke, having an aluminum alloy head and barrel, with an iron liner, a one-piece forged crankshaft with two flywheels running to keep the vibration down, and a duplex-chain primary drive to handle all that power going to the four-speed tranny. The factory claimed over 20 horsepower at 8,250 rpm—perhaps at the piston dome, but certainly not at the rear wheel.

Back in the 1950s 250cc and smaller motorcycles abounded all over Europe, providing cheap transportation in an economy that was still struggling to overcome the aftereffects of World War II. But as the world’s finances grew stronger, the utilitarian 250 gave way to the Volkswagen, Fiat 500, Austin A40, and the market for these utilitarian machines virtually vanished.

In the United States during the Eisenhower years this market never really existed, as it was only schoolboys who bought basic bikes with their earnings from a newspaper route, moving up to an old Ford or Plymouth when they could. Proper motorcycles, like big Harleys and BSA Road Rockets, belonged to the small group of enthusiasts most noted for having grease under their fingernails from all the maintenance and repairs that these bikes required.

In 1968 quarter-liter bikes were still popular but as sport rather than utility vehicles. Just about every manufacturer had one or two. Lots were two-strokes, like the Montesa Scorpion and Bultaco Metralla singles, or the Yamaha Catalina and Kawasaki Samurai twins, and a few four-stroke singles, like Ducati’s Mark 3 Desmo, Benelli’s Barracuda, Harley’s Aer­macchi 250 with a race-bred pushrod engine, and the rather unexciting British offerings, the Triumph TR25 and BSA Starfire. Those last two were very similar machines, differing only in styling and badges.

Since this was essentially a BSA product, we should take a look at its genesis. That 1938 C10 was a flathead engine with separate gearbox in a rigid frame, and after the war an OHV C11 version soon became available, in either a rigid or a plunger frame. The C12, appearing in 1956, used a swingarm frame. 1959 was the year of big change, with a unitized engine/transmission in the C15 Star. In best British tradition the crankcases were split vertically, which usually meant leaving drops of oil wherever the bike was parked. A 26mm Amal Monobloc carb was fitted.

The loop frame used a single downtube mating with a pair of tubes cradling the engine. A shrouded fork and shocks, and a nacelle around the headlight, were the antithesis of the sporting image. Years rolled on, sales were lackluster, and BSA decided it had to change the dowdy appearance. And performance. And name. The 1966 C15 Sportsman got the nacelle ripped off the headlight, open springs on the rear shocks, and a racy little hump at the back of the long, flat seat.
Good, but not good enough. The factory decided to spend some money, and the B25 Starfire appeared on the American market in 1968. A new cylinder barrel was cast, with the pushrod tunnel enclosed behind the newly squared-off fins. (A 441cc version, the B44, was also built, but that is another story.) A bigger 28mm Amal Concentric carburetor was fitted, a “hotter” camshaft, and the compression ratio went up to 10:1. A single set of points (so easy to adjust!) sat inside a little cover on the right side of the engine, and the electrics were 12 volt.

The very first Starfires to come into this country had the old skinny seven-inch brake drums on both 18-inch wheels, but that was soon changed to a full-width drum on the front. The frame was little changed from the C15, though the fork was improved with a double hydraulic damping system. And the metal covers protecting the sliders had now given way to sporty rubber gaiters! Yes, yes! The shrouding had come off the shock absorbers as well. And the rather dull oblong gas tank became an artfully contrived fiberglass container holding 2.5 gallons of fuel, with glorious sunburst BSA emblems. High test, please, as that compression ratio needed the best. Abbreviated chromed fenders and sculpted side panels and oil tank finished the new look, along with the chrome headlight shell and Smiths speedometer (missing on this one). Very pretty it was, in blue and white.

Put a leg over the saddle, bend down and flip the top bit of the kickstarter out 90 degrees, pull in the clutch and kick through to free the nine clutch plates, open the petcock, tickle the carb, turn on the ignition key in the steering head, and if the battery were up the engine should start in one kick. Maybe two or three if it is cold, because the Concentric does not have a choke. Make sure your right inner thigh does not connect with the cap on the oil tank.

Click down into first, the cush drive in the clutch smoothes the take-up, and away you motor. In-town work is a bit sluggish as the cam does not really function well at under 4,000 rpm. The fork has over five inches of travel, the shocks almost three, but the springs are on the stiff side of plush. If the road is smooth, the ride is comfortable. Now the oil is warm and you are in the country. If you are a sporting person, you might have sprung for the optional tachometer, but if not, the engine will certainly tell you when it is near the 8,000 rpm line. The speed tops out at almost 80 mph in fourth gear; you are exhilarated and consider the $750 well spent.

title: 1964 Alloy-Bodied Custom Coupe – “Duke of Earl”
description: Our 1964 Duke of Earl custom alloy-hand panel beated aluminum bodied coupe is based on early 60’s Triumph Spitfire Mk1 chassis and drivetrain. Epson created his unique coupe body with flowing curves and styling cues reminiscent of show and TV cars of the 1960’s. The alloy coupe is Earl’s only hardtop; his other 4 custom cars are aluminum-bodied roadsters built between 1962-1965. Notable design features of the coupe include gullwing doors, side pop-up headlights, and a streamlined aluminum body with oval side and rear windows. All 5 of Earl’s cars exist, with the Le May museum in Tacoma, WA a notable, multiple car owner. This coupe was Mr. Epson’s personal car, and he commuted from his home in Stanwood to his job in Everett, attracting considerable attention. Mr. Epson, who passed away a few years ago, was a talented designer, fabricator and auto restorer, specializing in panel beaten aluminum bodies and hand made parts. He was hired by the Mercedes Benz museum in Stuttgart, Germany to create an authentic hand formed metal parts for one of Hitler’s staff cars. The restoration of this car will undertaken by Jim Giordano, Dan Rogerson and Fred Vosk of Giordano’s Vintage Motors, and Gary Anderson, the car’s previous owner. Gary spent considerable time with Earl in his last few years. The Duke of Earl is presently being restored to driving condition. Mrs. Epson’s Earl roadster was involved in an accident, and Earl used his coupe’s front suspension assembly to repair her car. We are using parts from our Triumph Spitfire Mk1, an ex GT-6 powered, SCCA race car as donor to replace these missing parts. Future work may include installing an orange and white, 70’s style custom interior. Earl Epson is a unique local talent whose creative automotive designs and craftsmanship is deserving of attention. We look forward to displaying this car in our showroom, and at car events throughout the Northwest.

title: 1966 Honda S600 Roadster Project Car RHD Japan Market Car
description:
Dry Climate, Barn-Find 1966 Honda S600 Roadster in very restorable condition. Appears to be a Japan or Asia market car-its right hand drive, and dataplate is in Japanese. Originally Red paint with black interior.
Currently black primer.  Previous owner installed a BMC Austin Healey Sprite 948cc 4 cylinder engine and 4spd transmission apparently driving through the stock chain drive rear end!
Well engineered. Nearly complete car.
Body looks worse than it is. Floors, trunk and unibody are in overall very good condition, with some minor rust through on lower body. I think the very available, Honda N600 or z600 engine and transmissions will fit in this car, if owner wants to return to more original drivetrain. We are considering upgrading to a more powerful, Honda Motorcycle or small car engine. 
Currently accepting offers on this valuable, rare early Honda Roadster.

About the 1967 Mustang GTA Model:  The most desirable and valuable of the first-generation Mustangs are those from the 1967 and 1968 model years. These years represents the sweet spot, with the car’s classic style and compact (by American standards) size teamed with much better cosmetic, interior and mechanical specifications. 1967 Mustang Convertibles, especially with the GT Trim package are some of the most collectable, sought after mid-range American collectable cars from the 1960s. Terrific style, great parts availability, club support and low cost of ownership help to keep prices generally high and all 1967 Mustang models remain in steady and high demand. Appraiser’s Notes: The first impression I had of this car when the owner drove it to our dealership was of a remarkably original and well optioned Mustang, carefully maintained and kept in very good driving condition.
